awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Deformation of poroelastic nanoporous materials of hierarchical structure upon adsorption of gas mixtures: theory, molecular modeling and experiments
awd_abstract_narration:
The increased use of hydraulic fracturing to recover oil and gas from shale deposits has become one of the most rapidly growing components of the US economy. Located deep underground, shales are complex geological media comprised of both organic (e.g. kerogen) and inorganic fractions (e.g. clays, silicates). Up to 85% of the shale fuel is encapsulated in nanometer sized pores in the form of adsorbed hydrocarbon mixtures. Adsorbed hydrocarbons exert a stress on the shale, and in the process of recovery, this stress is released, which may decompress the shale and induce its deformation.  This compression/decompression has been observed to be over 20% in the kerogen fraction of the shale.  Deformation of the pores influences both their adsorption capacity and subsequent permeation of the fuel through the shale reservoir as it is recovered. Capacity and recovery rate influence the energy efficiency of the recovery process, as well as the amount of fuel recovered.  These effects can be exacerbated at the high temperatures and pressures typical of deep geological formations. An increased understanding of the interplay between fluid confinement in nanoporous media, the stresses this induces, and how these factors influence permeation and capacity will help optimize hydrocarbon recovery from shales. This project will combine statistical mechanics theory of poroelastic solids with novel high-pressure geophysical experimental measurements to develop a validated theory on adsorption-induced deformation of nanoporous media. 

The objective of the project is to couple the Gibbs theory of excess adsorption with the macroscopic Biot theory of poroelasticity.  The Biot theory describes how a porous body saturated with a fluid deforms under the action of fluid pressure and external stresses, whereas the Gibbs theory of excess adsorption describes how fluids concentrate near a surface, particularly in nanoporous adsorbents. Molecular lever models and Monte Carlo simulation will be used to explore phase behavior and separation of typical mixtures of light hydrocarbons and carbon dioxide in nanopores of compliant adsorbents and predict the adsorption capacity and selectivity, as well as the adsorbent stress and strain at given external conditions of pressure, temperature, and adsorbate mixture composition. The combined theory will be validated with experimental demonstration of adsorption stress of model materials interacting with high pressure gas mixtures. The project will establish new techniques for measuring the adsorbent stresses and strains in the process of adsorption of hydrocarbon mixtures. If successful, the project will converge theories from adsorption science with geophysics, and have further implications for the design of flexible adsorbents and separation membranes, actuators, nanobumpers, and energy storage devices. Two PhD and three undergraduate students will be trained within this project. Educational and community outreach program facilitates student recruitment from underrepresented minority groups, summer opportunities for high school students and teachers, participation is special events such as Girl to Engineering Day and STEM Festival. Novel simulation methods and case-study topics will be incorporated into PIs graduate courses on Nanoscale Thermodynamics and Transport and Advanced Geomechanics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Project objective. This collaborative research program focuses on the synergetic development of novel theoretical, modeling, and experimental techniques to study adsorption-induced deformation of nanoporous adsorbents with relevance on separation of hydrocarbon and CO2 mixtures. There are two major practical applications: adsorption separation of hydrocarbons from natural gas on porous membranes and oil and gas recovery coupled with carbon dioxide sequestration from coal and shale reservoirs. While the former represents one of the classical problems in adsorption science and technology, the latter is relatively new, technologically challenging, and much less developed. Shale reservoirs represent hierarchical porous media with various organic (kerogen) and inorganic (clay, silicates) fractions, which contain hydrocarbons in nanometer size pores. The processes of adsorption and desorption of hydrocarbons may result in significant stress gradients and deformation of nanoporous matrixes affecting material sorption capacity and permeability. Optimization of hydrocarbon separation and shale hydrocarbon recovery requires a better understanding and characterization of thermodynamic properties of hydrocarbon mixtures confined in nanoscale pores, which differ substantially from the properties in the bulk, and adsorption-induced deformation effects, especially, at geological conditions.

The intellectual merit of the theoretical efforts is multifold. We have incorporated the Gibbs theory of excess adsorption into the Biot theory of poroelasticity, which describes how a porous body saturated with a fluid deforms under the action of fluid pressure and external stress. The proposed theoretical approach provide a new methodological framework for the extension of the poromechanical equations to account for the adsorption stress induced by adsorbate-solid interactions. Based on the theoretical and molecular lever models of nanoporous adsorbents, Monte Carlo simulation, and molecular density functional theory, we explored the specifics of adsorption and deformation of typical nanoporous adsorbents, including micro- and mesoporous carbons and silicas of hierarchical structure, metal-organic frameworks, and model geosorbents. Ultimate goal is to predict the phase behavior and separation of typical mixtures of light hydrocarbons and carbon dioxide in nanopores of compliant adsorbents including the adsorption capacity, selectivity, as well as the adsorbent stress and strain at given external conditions of pressure, temperature, and adsorbate mixture composition. Correlation of the modeling and experimental data collected at by our experimental partner Dr. Espinoza at UT-Austin on particular samples of specially synthesized carbon sample provided by our international collaborators may suggest modifications of our theoretical and computational models of adsorption deformation to account for the specific geometrical features of materials.

Novel modeling methods are developed for studies of the adsorbent deformation in the process of binary adsorption, with a particular emphasis on the displacement of natural gas by carbon dioxide from coal and shale reservoirs. To this end, the original  three-dimensional molecular models of carbon and kerogen nanostructures are designed and implemented for predicting the adsorption capacity and selectivity and also for characterization of the pore structure morphology from measured adsorption isotherms of particular molecular probes. Collaboration with ExxonMobil trough internship supplements for PhD students helped to apply the developed modeling tools to practical problems and establish fruitful university-industry collaborations. Special computational tools are designed for analysis of phase equilibria and pore structure characterization of metal-organic frameworks.

The broad impact of the research and educational program is versatile. The project results will have an interdisciplinary transformative impact, since the phenomenon of adsorption induced deformation is currently actively explored not only with respect to separation and production and of hydrocarbons and carbon sequestration, but also for the design of novel flexible adsorbents, separation membranes, actuators, nanobumpers, and energy storage devices. The computational methods developed are documented and implemented in the open-source software packages and internet depositories for public use.

Over the 5 years, the project trained 1 postdoc, 4 PhD students (1 minority student, 2 graduated) 2 PhD international exchange students, and 10 undergraduate students (4 female students, 2 summer REU students). The graduated students found and found exiting carrier positions in industry (Silvio Dantas at Merck) and academia (Rich Cimino at NJIT). All 4 female students continue graduate studies (Lizy Hinks at Stanford and Aasta Kasera at Northwestern). The students benefited from the exchanges with the international collaborators, learning the novel methods of synthesis and characterization of nanomaterials advanced in their labs. Supplemental INTERN-ships of PhD student (Nick Corrente and Shivam Parashar) at ExxonMobil greatly expanded their training opportunities and helped acquire the practical academic and communication skill for further carrier development.  The simulation methods developed and case-study systems explored are included into the graduate course on "Nanoscale Thermodynamics and Transport" developed by Rutgers PI for the IGERT curriculum.

The project results are disseminated in 16 published papers with additional 6 manuscripts submitted and in preparation and presented at major international and national meetings, invited lectures and seminar in leading academic and industrial setttings.
